reviews.text: All the times we ever visited Barcelona, we get close to Eixample, one time, four years ago, we had the opportunity to stay in a beautiful modernist apartment with a amazing balcony where we could admire the architecture and the life at the streets of quarter.
We stayed at the Casa Mimosa in this district and (like walking) found it 'spot on' for walking the entire City and touristic spots....20 mins Las Ramblas etc. nice and clean and quiet
Lots of shopping.  A plethora of restaurants and friendly shopkeepers.  Bustling nightlife and easy to navigate.   Definitely an area to explore.
Sorry I just find this noisy, polluted pickpocketing capital so un charming . Take even Nisantasi in Istanbul over this. Ashamed to have this being a part of Europe....
Wonderful neighbourhood, with beautiful streets and lanes. here you can find shops, housed in beautiful buildings and Gaudí architecture.
There are several amazing buildings in this area, but a walk down any street in L'Eixample would be an architectural delight.

Lots of neighbourhood pubs, restaurants and tapas bars around every corner as well as small shops catering to all your basic needs. It's within a 15 minute walk to shopping along La Rambla and some very interesting areas along the way. It's a safe middle class area.

This area has become the symbol of Barcelona with its gridlike layout. This is Modernista architecture is what characterizes this area and what makes it so pleasant to the eye and also great to walk around. There is not only lots of great architecture (the great unfinished Sagrada Familia, Casa Milla, Casa Amatller, Casa Batllo, and others maybe less famous, but still great to see), but also a restaurant, a shop, supermarket, bar at walking distance.

We love this area, and choose to stay in this district each visit. The wide streets make it feel so open despite the huge busy city you're in.  Great traffic flow and good pedestrian walkways, and of course tons of restaurants and shopping.

If you love taking long walks on small old streets, this is totally worthy:) i love wondering on the streets, occasionally stop for a coffee or for something sweet. You can also buy some souvenirs. The streets are safe and although there are lots of tourists, it is not that crowded. I enjoyed a nice long walk on a sunny afternoon

Every block is 250m square with 5-10 restaurants per block. Very safe area with beautiful architecture, easy access to the train and metro. From Avinguda Diagonal it's only a 20 minute walk to most of Barcelona's amazing sites. Many hotels to choose from in the L'Eixample District. I would not hesitate to stay in this area again.

This area is full of beauty and architecture, as well as high-end shops. I prefer the first, the buidlings, not the shops! Every building has elaborate architecture, and even the lamp posts have been made to look incredible. Take your time to look around by walking, and looking up to see buidling details that give this area it's grandeur. You will find some of Gaudi's work here too.  And if you have cash to spare, the Passeig de Gracia high-end stores will take care of that
This is a residential district but with many interesting shops and boutiques, fabulous food markets and stores.  Also, feels very safe and much less crowded than the Gotic quarter.
cool place to wander around with different shops. There is a long line of sellers that has cool souvenirs in front of La Sagra da familia,

If you want to tour the most dense collection of Modernista architectural style, this is the place to come.  Lots of gorgeous high-styled buildings in this vast area.  Also Sagrada Familia.  Lots of great places to eat and drink. Cabs widely available,
Stayed in a 19th century apartment building - 5 bedrooms!  With a lift elevator and enclosed balcony, broad streets outside and a pace of daily life that is very enticing.
Full of shops, wide streets to walk and great places to eat and have coffee.  Around you can find several metro stations that connect with the centre and Barceloneta.

By offering La Sagrada Familia and multiple other Gaudi buildings,  this area draws countless visitors. It is actually a charming part of the city, certainly loaded with tourist shops that seem to look alike after awhile, but it is worth just walking around and having a bite to eat at many of its small but very good eateries. the architecture is stunning and is worth a slow walk through the streets. One could make a whole day or more seeing Gaudi structures and the Recinte Modernista de Sant Pau
we followed Rick Steve's walk and were duly impressed.  the various architectural styles are well represented.  getting there and back from the Ramblas was easy by Metro.
Wonderful area.  Tons of shopping experiences, Tapas and sights.  Great walking area with easy transportation.  Loved the area!
Location is very central to many activities. You can walk to those places on foot. Very safe location to stay at.
By not being in the tourist area you get better cheaper food and less hassle. And you can walk or take the subway anywhere you want to go

As Barcelona Matured the cities people move dingo this newer more fashionable part of town which now hosts some of its finest streets, homes and businesses. Worth visiting It’s many shops and attractions.

This area is very well to do. The stores and restaurants I noted are all premium or good quality and not budget. The mandarin oriental and Chanel are here for example.

A lovely area to explore with a purpose (like me and Gaudí buildings) or just to experience the area.
I stayed in this area for my stay in Barcelona.  It was away from the hustle and bustle of Catalunya.  There was some nice cafes, and restaurants about.  A few 24 hour convenience stores close by.
We stayed in this area of town.  It is clean, vibrant, has many stores - both retail and grocery stores.  A nice place to walk around

We stayed at the Casa Mimosa here in Eixample.  It was a nice area, filled with restaurants and shops. Easy access to subways and transportation.  Just be mindful that there is Gucci, Prada, Chanel, Louis, etc. on the Passeig de Gracia so if you want to save money, this is not the place.  But very ideal!  Loved the stay minus the riots.

We had a 2 bedroom 2 bathroom apartment through unTours.  We learned all about our neighborhood, its restaurants, grocery stores and market, and the bakeries.  A great location near three Metro stops.
Walk for 20 minutes up from Place Catalunya and come to restaurants and shops and apartments and hotels that are out of the madding crowd.
This area can be really lovely with lots of the best buildings to view. At the weekend we caught a nice pedestrianised area with stalls to stroll around.

Our hotel Sixtytwo as located in this district on Passig Gracias.  It has a lot of high end shopping as well as Casa Batllo.  Our hotel was in the middle of Eixample so it was close to all major attraction and taxi's as well as the underground were very close.  The La Rambla Catyluna was one street from our hotel and we were 15 - 20 minute walk to Columbus statue near cruise ship dock.
Don’t miss it, watch, shop, take a seat, have a drink and a nice meal, enjoy! Exceptional area with exceptional people and service surrounding it.
A "planned community" that is pedestrian friendly providing a nice area to walk, wide sidewalks, outdoor dining, etc. Very nice vibe here.

Ideal for travelling in to Central Barcelona, lots of restaraunts and shops nearby . Good hotels too.
Avenue Diagonal is an ideal place to have a walk down all the way from Camp Nou to the Beachfront, architecture is stunning with lots of detail . L'Eixample has the famous Dry Martini bar, which is a gem. Spolied for choice here.
This area is very nice and lively.  Full of cafes, bakeries, restaurants and hotels.  Within walking distance of many attractions.
You can't miss L'Eixample part of Barcelona -- literally -- if you visit downtown BCN, you're there. It's the center of everything.

L'Eixample couldn't be more of a contrast as an area to El Born and Barri Gotic. It is well planned, spacious and by comparison, modern. And of course, full of the most amazing Moderne architect, mush of it domestic. It's a great pleasure just to wonder the streets and happen serendipitously upon these treasures, chief amongst then Sagrada Famiglia, of course. 
The area is crammed with restaurants, bars, cafes, great shopping opportunities and other sorts of entertainment. It's sunny, with wide well planned avenues and generally an easy place to be.
Lovely area with easy access to all the major sightseeing places and the Rambla. This is where our hotel was in a quiet back street
Nearby our hotel and also has some Gaudi sites.  Casa Battlo and Casa Milo.   Lots of amazing architectural buildings.   Have lunch outside in one of the many cafes.
Good restaurants, good bars, friendly people, many public transit options: what more can one ask for?
A very pleasant walkable area. Our hotel was situated in this area and it was a pleasure to wander about. Pretty cafes and lovely shops.

We stayed in a hotel in this neighborhood our first two nights.  It's a very friendly neighborhood with many sidewalk cafes and great food.  It was really wonderful to "live among the locals".  Would stay here again!

We discovered quickly that we were very close to almost anywhere we wanted to go in Barcelona via public transit. Just a block and a half away from the Girona Metro station.... and barely a block away to some of the most original food at BetLem Restaurant.
Here the streets are straight and right-angled. It looks like a chessboard. This quater was build up new when the old part of the city extended
We stayed in the eixample and it was great. Perfect relief from the chaos of the center and just as beautful. A lot of nice modernist architecture to see and nice cafes and restaurants.

Stayed in the area in August, it was busy but felt safe. A recommended area for a visit to Barcelona. I would only pick here or El bourn to stay for a return visit, easily the nicest areas in Barcelona.

This is a large and popular district of Barcelona city . Close to the heart so that it can be a nice stroll to get to La Rumbla or there are several metros that can get you around quickly depending on where you are located. We were nearer to La Sagrada familia . Safe , friendly and walking distance to designer shops, simple tapas bars, fancy tapas bars , more bohemian sections. Overall a lovely area

The Exaimple district is very large and encompasses many neighborhoods, all of which have their own special characteristics, from the very posh area around Passeig de Gracia with the international designer shops and lovely apartments buildings to the Modernistic architecture of Gaudi's La Pedrera and Basilica of Sagrada
Familia to some funky shops and family neighborhoods, and trendy cafes and bars on narrow streets.  We stayed in the Sant Antoni market area and were able get everywhere from the close by metro station or walking to restaurants and markets.  We felt very safe walking around the neighborhood at night, which was very lively with young couples out strolling, families and even young children playing on the play structures until after10 pm.  We were very happy with our neighborhood and would recommend this district to all visitors to Barcelona.
This area is adjacent to Casa Batllo, and you could walk through the neighbourhood towards the Barcelona University campus, and then back to the Gothic quarters.

Wonderful area with much to do.  From top notch high end shopping, great food and drink to amazing Gaudi.  Castle Milia is here along with the block of discord.  About 4 block from each other.  It's a wonderful peak into history.  There is also a great traditional market about 6 blocks from Castle Milia too.  Good place for lunch and enjoying a lovely stroll.

As with much of the city the centre is very crowded, not in an uncomfortable way just locals & tourists alike going about they're business. You have shops plus eateries aplenty or just simply sit on a shaded bench taking in the atmosphere the choice is yours.

The most stunning 1800's area that was reclaimed to open up the city for residential use.  Now it's a lot of upscale offices and retail space but some very nice hotels abound and it's location is  perfect for walking Barcelona
If you like architecture, just walk through the streets of Eixample Dret, and you will find true jewels of modernism, one after the other.
Love this area of Barcelona!  The best restaurants, shopping and walking streets.  We stayed at Hotel Murmuri in this location which was incredible!

This area, north of Pl. Catalunya was started in the 19th century and is now an upmarket and fashionable district. With long wide streets, flanked by designer shops and expensive restaurants, it is so relaxing, just walking round and taking in the sights and sounds. The architecture is beautiful, with many modernista buildings, including some of Gaudi's work, including Casa Batllo. Passeig de Gracia is a grand, wide boulevard and I do like sitting at one of the many cafes, just watching the world go by.
This area is a very pretty area with shopping galore and restaurants, beautiful buildings, clean streets, and lots to see.  Plenty of bus stops too.
We wondered around the area and saw some pretty cool Architecture. There's the unique Gaudio building, which is unique and beautiful. There's also a ton of other nice buildings.
Went here many times to shop and dine. So many things to do while you are here. If here you must go to El Nationale (even if to look around).
We enjoyed our stay in this quiet neighborhood. It has everything you need, somewhat aside of other hectic parts of the city.
Very nice neighborhood, with a mix of tourists and locals. We stayed closed by the Hospital San Pau and found nice little local places to have breakfast very affordable but with great food.
Kind of expensive, but all of Barcelona was, and we couldn't believe how central we were to everything.  Also, just very enjoyably quiet and walkable streets.
So much culture to discover without the madness of crowds! stores, restaurants, bars, night life, the way locals enjoy it
This district is in the best district of Barcelona in my opinion. We stayed here and was in good distance to everything.

When the old walled town could no longer house the growing city, the 'expansion'  was born.   It's grid is softened with cutoff corners to admit more light and air.  You will find luxury shopping, large parks, and elegant restaurants here.

We rode and walked through this part of Barcelona while on our tour to Sagrada Familia and La Pedrera. This is a beautiful, well-designed part of the city with lots of shops and restaurants. We wish we had had more time to walk and explore this area. Would definitely consider finding a place to stay in this part of the city the next time we are in Barcelona.

My group and I stayed in the L'Eixample District for 5 weeks and were very pleased with our choice. It's centrally located, making it easy to walk to many of the city's attractions. The many shops and restaurants to covered all of our needs.

This is my idea of what a city should be: walkable, full of all life's necessities (supermarkets, bookstores, schools, restaurants, shady places on sunny days, many benches to sit on while you are taking a long walk, sidewalk cafés, pharmacies--it's all here).
A lovely area to stroll about and to appreciate the transportation layout of the neighborhood both for walkers and drivers.

We spent 2 weeks in an apartment in this area which turned out to  be great as we had no idea of the many amenities when we booked.  Enjoyed so much this residential area with its wide boulevards, tree lined streets, patios, close to grocery stores, shops, wonderful restaurants, 2 Metro stops and walking distance to Sagara Familia.
Very easy area to navigate, walk to city center, walk to subway for Segrada Familia, great shopping, very nice neighbourhood.

We stayed in a hotel in the middle of this district and we enjoyed it very much. It's probably a bit further west than totally desirable - but close to the Sagrada which is nice. A good 25 min walk to The Boqueria. Lovely area though and just a bit quieter than the main streets.
We were lucky enough to be there when they had a street festival celebrating the area which was v cool.

I stayed my entire visit in this neighbourhood. I loved it! It has great restaurants and bars as well as super walkable. It isn't really far from the "main" tourist attractions. Close to Placa Catalunya, Casa Batllo, La Pradera etc. Its a slower place than staying close to La Ramblas or the Gothic Quarter and less touristy. I highly recommend!
We just drove through this district, it was a nice quiet area and a lot of history to it. There are a few shops in the area.

We lived in the Eixample for four months thirty years ago, and it won our hearts back then, and the love affair continues. Although it's changed quite a bit in terms of the restaurants and stores, you can still find the local bars and tiendas owned by the same families for generations. Everything you need is found here, plus it's in walking distance to things wonderful about Barcelona.

A grid pattern of streets show all of Gaudi’s architectural prototypes. He designed many buildings in Barcelona some of which are being used as museums, some are apartments, some are offices. Each are unique in itself. Grab a map and walk the entire L’Eixample district
We were very fortunate to stay in this gorgeous area.  It is so convenient to transportation and walkable to so many other areas. Lots of Gaudi , shopping, restaurants, and cafes.

L'Eixample District is a lovely area. There lots of shops to do your shopping till you drop, if you wish. There are many cafes and restaurants too. The architecture is stunning and that alone is a reason to visit this beautiful place.
Family of 5 stayed in a beautiful 3 bed apartment. The area is clean and fairly quiet. It is built up but then we are in the City Centre. Lovely area to eat, drink & be merry.

This area has numerous shops, restaurants, bars and many of the most important sights in Barcelona including, for example, Sagrada Familia, Casa Mila-La Pedrera, and Casa Batllo.

The beautiful architecture is characterized by long straight streets and square blocks with chamfered corners.

We stopped on carrer balmes which was really close to great restaurants, cervezeria catalana, and sagrada. Perfect for walking around the rambla and gothic areas as they were about two kilometres away.

Strolling through L'Eixample district on a sunny day was one of my most pleasant experiences in Barcelona.  People watching, popping into shops, slowly strolling on wide generous sidewalks- if that's your jam you'll love L'Eixample.

Our friends hotel was in this area, we walked over from our hotel and it was mostly apartments and offices with a scattering of some bars and restaurants but, not a lot like some of the other areas of Barcelona.

This area of town is extremely nice. It offers many parks and outdoor places of beauty, gorgeous buildings, incredible shopping and many choices of great restaurants. Shopping around Turow Park is incredible!!
Fifth Avenue type, upscale neighborhood with better architecture. Mant good restaurants and shops. Easy access to hotels.

We stayed in an AirB&B here that was within feet of the Metro, walkable to Sagrada Familia, and with great restaurants nearby. Loved meeting residents of our apartment building. Sad my Spanish couldn't keep up with theirs.
This is good area to explore when in Barcelona and there are many shops and bars and restaurants in the area.

Barcelona has become a little insecure over the years and there are areas you cannot walk around alone at night so I did my research and decided to stay in L'eixample. It was relatively close to all the main tourist attractions and I was able to walk almost everywhere. I felt save walking at night around there and I didn't feel in the middle of all the touristy chaos.
Great Steaks (Rib - Eye), Great Service (At nearly Midnight), Bessy (Waitress) Was Lovely To My Wife and I (And Learnt Some Welsh!!)
High end shops, architectural delights and sadly many, many beggars & homeless people.  Better to stick to the streets a few blocks back either way.
Excellent place for pubs and tapas bars. The crowd is also nice. I found it slightly expensive but a do visit when in Barcelona

Our airbnb was located in the district and it was perfect. It is easy to walk to main areas, or take the metro, but it felt more like we were living in Barcelona and less like we were tourists. Every restaurant was good, fun bars, welcoming people, busy enough and quiet enough for us.

I like to walk cities.. some days strolling over 10 miles, and L’Eixample is a fine strolling area...some blocks were worth second or even third stroll in different lighting.  My hotel was in this general area, and I found it most enjoyable.
If you're moving to Barcelona, this is, in my humble opinion, the perfect neighborhood for living. Not as crowded as Ciutat Vella and nicer !

I stayed in the L'Eixample District and enjoyed just walking out the door to find good shopping within ten minutes. And it was a very quiet residential part of town. But if you want to hit all the tourist areas it takes 20 to 30 minutes on the metro to get around. So you should consider where you want to go before you book your hotel.

We were hosted in Eixample, and walked to Park Guell, Sagrada Familia, all Gaudi,s houses, complete Ramblas, Paseo de Gracia, Gotic area, Market places (Sant Antoni and Boqueria), etc, etc. Best travel to Barcelona, ever!
Every corner has a gem.  Camera out and enjoy the architecture.  Also the Bond Street of Barcelona.  All the designer shops plus numerous classic casa's, wide streets and plenty of classy restaurants
We lowed walking in this area, and discover its museums, restaurants, bars, etc. Excellent shops and cafeterias
Since we tend to prefer the beauty of the older parts of cities, this area, although interesting, is more modern than we usually are attracted to.
This area is walking district to restaurants..shopping..grocery shopping...Sagrada Familia..Las Ramblas..Safe area..many hotels and apartments to stay in...bus stops all over this area..
We enjoyed this area and were happy to find some streets to walk around without hundreds of tourists surrounding you.
